name: Free Bird 1.5
description: Still no playtest. Let me know if this deck actually work.

name: Wrecking Ball
description: Keep their ice off the field with a combination of Patel's ability, Datasucker/Parasite recursion and Unscheduled Maintenance.

name: The Ice Tax
Quetzal The CriminArch v3.0
description:
Run early. Run often.

Quetzal's ability lets us play Anarchs like we would Criminals, so get that early pressure on those servers using any number of nasty tricks, and run them again as soon as you can with Same Old Thing. The hallmark Anarch disruption cards are in here in the form of Keyhole, Parasite, and Demo Run, and we can pressure across the board with Knight/Overmind/D4v1d all comboed with e3. A notable omission is Datasucker, but this deck doesn't have too much trouble dealing with middling ice (those pesky 4 strengthers), so I've always found it best to just plop down a Parasite and wait for it to tick away. Worst case scenario, you'll force the corp to cede tempo with a virus wipe.

Hades Shard has been a bone of contention for this deck, and I'm still torn as to whether it needs to run in here. For now though, it's in because of how darn well it synergizes with Keyhole. The trade-off here is that e3 is down to only two copies, but I've had success with this deck even when you see the e3's late, so I'd rather leave that 2 influence for the Hades and a Net Celebrity (Cerebral Static is a nightmare for this deck).

D4v1d is down to two copies to allow room for two Plascretes. Weyland's coming back in a big way, and it's time to start suiting up against the Scorched again. Overall, I think this is a tighter build that should start netting more consistent results.

Give it a try, and tell me how it works for you!

name: Nope. (No. v1.5)
description:
Updated to include Eliza's for rezzing OtG and some bigger ICE when you'd rather save your credits for rezzing other bigger ICE. Interns for pulling back ICE or trashed assets/upgrades.

Still pretty weak early game despite low density of agendas. Would love to find a way to tighten that up.

name: Marathon Running v 1.3
description:
This deck is based on BCavalier's doppelganger test deck. I built it to really take advantage of free run events (or even getting paid for run events) and then to combo those run events into single powerful turns.

Doppelganger combos beautifully with a number of cards in this deck. For example:

First click indexing, doppel back into R&D to score.

First click demo run, doppel to bounce off an ETR to trigger John M.'s tag. Then, DLR for two clicks and run on archives to access three cards.

Doppelganger + John M. + 2 Security testing nets $4 and a card for one run.

First click run HQ (or use one of the HQ event runs), 2nd click EO on the server you want to hit, 3rd click run and doppel run, fourth click recover or hit the server again.

Doppel into any central 2x to load up on datasucker tokens.

So, while I love all these combos (and when I've managed to pull them off successfully they have been a thing of beauty) they also seem to be very expensive and my rig just isn't cutting through ICE like I'd like it to. Any ideas for how to improve this?

name: Yon - Overdrive Draft - Runner [winner]
description: This was my Runner deck in the Overdrive draft we did at the office (5 person draft) with 2 rounds of 4 games each. This runner deck lost 3 out of those games.

name: Yon - Overdrive Draft - Corp [winner]
description:
This was my corp deck in the Overdrive draft we did at the office (5 person draft) with 2 rounds of 4 games each. This deck lost only once - my first game - when I was milled because I didn't pace myself correctly for a draft game.

The NEXT suite + Mushin was amazing

name: Incidental Check
description:
An aggressive denial Reina deck. Run hard from turn one. An early Desperado and/or John Masanori can be useful for getting extra from your runs.

Knights can be used to quickly defuse servers or snipe well defended agendas. Events like Dirty Laundry help you keep afloat as you put pressure on the Corp's economy (via Reina's ability and Xanadu). Parasite/Datasucker for additional griefing.

Keyhole is not a main strategy, but you can default to it easily enough if the remotes dry up. Move all Knights to R&D and just go to town. If you don't spot agendas, Keyhole economy next.

There are some good resources, as well as cards that can tag which is a bit of a non-bo, but if you're keeping the Corp poor enough, they're unlikely to stump up the cash to trash your stuff.

Some other cards for flavour:
Cyber Threat has a nice pseudo-FAO effect that combos with Masanori on servers that only have unrezzed ICE (i.e. facecheck without the tag).
Singleton Account Siphon for the surprise. I've played many games where when Keyhole hits the table, Corps give up defending HQ so this is a nice one-two punch. Same Old Thing can recur if needed. A couple of other singletons to help you out in a jam (e.g. Dyson Mem Chip for memory issues, Quality Time for digging or Jinteki glory runs if needed, e3 Feedback Implants for stacked bioroids and Knights)
Plascrete Carapace because Netrunner

name: Big Brother is Always Watching
description:
Hello, Citizen! Welcome to gorgeous SanSan City, where we bring you all the vid that's fit to view, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. From Breaking News to our top-ranked AstroScript Pilot Programs, there's always something on your vidscreen for you to enjoy. Don't get tripped up by those Pop-up Windows!

Sweeps Week is coming up, so we've enlisted the help of our good friend Jackson Howard to guide you through our treasure trove of shows, from sensies to threedee. Joining the you on your journey into the world of NBN are two of Mr. Howard's best friends, Data Hound and his pal Data Raven.

We've been performing plenty of Market Research in order to provide you with all the Targeted Marketing that you didn't even know you wanted. From coverage of the latest Jinteki Corporation Celebrity Gifts to broadcasts of Haas-Bioroid's hot new Eve Campaigns, you might even say it's TMI! To keep yourself from Information Overload, we recommend taking the occasional break from our televised programming. May we suggest streaming some music off your PAD?

Citizen, underworldly types often Snoop around NBN's network and bring back their own brand of news. They claim that we're guilty of Invasions of Privacy. They compare us to figments of fiction and their imaginations, calling us "Big Brother". NBN refuses to stand idly by while these troublemakers spread their false accusations and attempt to commit Character Assassination against our wonderful organization. We urge you not to blindly believe everything you see or hear.

NBN is proud to provide you with all of your modern-day media needs. Our sophisticated software algorithms ensure that you're always watching the content that's right for you, and our extensive network infrastructure gets you that content faster than ever before. It's a great time to be alive, and we're so happy that you can benefit from our unparalleled expertise in media, user-friendliness, and more.

And remember, when it comes to NBN, someone is always watching.

This is totally a joke deck. The writeup was pretty fun, and playing the deck probably would be too.

name: The Shape of Shadows
description:
I have been using this deck for a while now and it is terrifying to play against. It runs most servers for free and can when piloted well produce a hard R&D Lock.

Helpful ai and underworld contacts produces the 3 real credits I need per turn as well as giving me an emergency boost for my stealth breakers when I need it.

You definitely do not need all stealth cards in play to make full use of this deck. Clone chips are usually used for SMC to get the other cloaks once the breakers are down.

All in all this is probably my favorite shaper deck to date. You haven't lived until youve broken a janus and an archer in the same server for zero actual credits.

name: trust in the mill. believe in the mill.
description:
been running this on octgn for a few days. extremely powerful, has caused several ragequits. still somewhat early draft but incredibly fun to play and effective against lots of different corps.

largely mill-based, mulligan for wyldside to get everything moving. darwin + d4v1d will get you through most things. lotus field and tactical purges will lock you out, so you have to Trust The Mill to save you. tempted to put in one knight to deal with that but idk, Knight is very cumbersome in a wyldside deck without deep red.

get same old thing on the table for the LARLA. use the money to avoid tags and don't run too aggressively on a rich weyland. lamprey is largely just for the mill rather than actually useful, but a mill and a credit from Scher is rad.

fun decks y'all

name: Attention Seeker v1.3
Switch v 1.1
Attention Seeker
Switch.
Wisp of MSGs
description:
OK this is a fairly simple concept the tries to exploit The Foundry: Refining the Process using multiple copies of many ICE.

Akitaro Watanabe is brilliant with Chimera and pretty much any type of NEXT ice. In the process you make big servers one at a time using multiple ICE with more than one subroutine (Enigma, Ichi 1.0, NEXT Silver, Eli 1.0 and Datapike). Whenever you are comfortable being able to afford it just slap on a Midway Station Grid and tax the runner like crazy. Don't worry about trashing Mr Akitaro once you're comfortable just to put another copy somewhere else and using Jackson Howard to place him back in RnD afterwards.

Will-o'-the-Wisp is great because you can just mess them up big time with Chimera afterwards and Successful Demonstration is surprisingly handy for econ since runners don't mind running naked at first and your barrier of entry is cheap so long as you stop them once.

name: Wisp of MSGs 1.1
description:
Minor edits from the original: I swapped Datapike for Viktor 2.0 and Priority Requisition for Project Wotan in order to really maximize on exploiting Midway Station Grid. Also added an Eden Fragment since you'll be doing plenty of installing.

OK this is a fairly simple concept the tries to exploit The Foundry: Refining the Process using multiple copies of many ICE.

Akitaro Watanabe is brilliant with Chimera and pretty much any type of NEXT ice. In the process you make big servers one at a time using multiple ICE with more than one subroutine (Enigma, Ichi 1.0, NEXT Silver, Eli 1.0 and Viktor 2.0 ). Whenever you are comfortable being able to afford it just slap on a Midway Station Grid and tax the runner like crazy. Don't worry about trashing Mr Akitaro once you're comfortable just to put another copy somewhere else and using Jackson Howard to place him back in RnD afterwards.

Will-o'-the-Wisp is great because you can just mess them up big time with Chimera afterwards and Successful Demonstration is surprisingly handy for econ since runners don't mind running naked at first and your barrier of entry is cheap so long as you stop them once.

name: Wake up in a dumpster
description: That's what happens when you spend All Night at Duggar's

name: Pandora's BOX-E
description: Concept Overmind deck at the moment. Uses new BOX-E console for 2 extra MU. Public Sympathy to deal with scorch by virtue of having a huge hand size. I'm sure that this is a steaming pile, but I think it's worth while testing. Note I don't have 3 Scavenge but to be perfectly honest when I play against people using this deck it usually seems like they have waaaay too many ways to refresh their Overmind and not enough support to actually run. Currently missing permanent multi-access, might swap the Imp's for Medium and/or Nerve Agent if I think they're necessary.

name: Stealthy Nasir v1
description:
Not sure if this has been published; but here's my Stealth Nasir deck.

Pretty straightforward. Run on a low budget, using whatever tools pop up.

Recursion if needed.

Has been doing well so far.
